title: How to Diagnose Vomiting in Dogs
profile: Most dog owners will experience their dog being vomiting at one time or another. However, vomiting is a symptom of a problem, rather than a diagnosis. X Trustworthy Source Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine Leading veterinary medicine training institution and biomedical research center Go to source Underlying causes of vomiting range widely, for example the dog eating something it shouldn't, physical problems, such as a foreign body stuck in the gut, or vomiting as a complication of another condition, such as liver or kidney disease. Because it can have such a wide range of causes, a vomiting dog should be watched closely and taken to a veterinarian if the symptoms are serious.

step_items.content: Gauge how serious the vomiting is. There are hundreds of different conditions that can cause vomiting. If your pet vomits regularly for 4 hours, vomits as a result of feeling unwell, vomits water back, or seems well but has vomited occasionally for longer than 24 hours, then the situation is likely serious. WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');

Decide when to seek veterinary help. As a rule of thumb, if you are concerned about your dog, respect your instincts and at the very least phone a veterinary office for advice. If your dog vomits once and is acting normal afterward, you may not need to take them to the vet. However, if the dog is acting differently and/or if the vomiting persists, you may need to go to the vet. If your dog is retching and nothing comes up, or if its stomach looks swollen and bloated, then contact a veterinary surgeon immediately, as this can be a sign of bloat (gastric torsion) which needs immediate attention. \n<\/p><\/div>"} If the dog is being repeatedly sick and is unable to keep water down, and the sickness persists for more than 4 hours, the dog is liable to get dehydrated so contact the vet. If you suspect your dog has eaten a toy or something else it shouldn't, then go to the vet. If the dog is extremely depressed and dull, there is blood in the vomit, you suspect he has had access to a toxin, or he may have eaten a toy then also contact the vet. Likewise if the dog also has diarrhea, is not vaccinated, or its gums look yellow or pale, contact the vet. Fever and pain, are also indications that a dog needs to be seen.

If the dog is being repeatedly sick and is unable to keep water down, and the sickness persists for more than 4 hours, the dog is liable to get dehydrated so contact the vet.
If you suspect your dog has eaten a toy or something else it shouldn't, then go to the vet.
If the dog is extremely depressed and dull, there is blood in the vomit, you suspect he has had access to a toxin, or he may have eaten a toy then also contact the vet.
Likewise if the dog also has diarrhea, is not vaccinated, or its gums look yellow or pale, contact the vet. Fever and pain, are also indications that a dog needs to be seen.

step_items.content: Don't ignore vomiting. Some dogs repeatedly vomit due to stress or overeating. Consult with your veterinarian if this is the case. In general, vomiting usually indicates a problem. This problem may be temporary and not serious, but your dog still needs to be monitored just to make sure. Dogs that vomit every few days but on a regular basis need to be checked out by a veterinarian.
children: Dogs that vomit every few days but on a regular basis need to be checked out by a veterinarian.

step_items.content: Take your dog to a veterinarian. The vet will take a history, and ask questions about access to toxins, if the dog is a scavenger, and does it chew toys. Next, the vet will perform a physical examination and check to see if the dog is dehydrated, if it looks anemic or jaundiced, check it for a fever, and feel its abdomen. X Trustworthy Source Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine Leading veterinary medicine training institution and biomedical research center Go to source When the vet palpates the dog's tummy, he or she is feeling for areas of pain and discomfort, checking the size and position of the gut, liver, spleen, kidneys, and bladder, plus checking to see if the dog can feel any obstructions. In overweight or giant dogs this information can be limited. X Trustworthy Source Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine Leading veterinary medicine training institution and biomedical research center Go to source
children:
When the vet palpates the dog's tummy, he or she is feeling for areas of pain and discomfort, checking the size and position of the gut, liver, spleen, kidneys, and bladder, plus checking to see if the dog can feel any obstructions. In overweight or giant dogs this information can be limited.[5]
	X
		Trustworthy Source

step_items.content: Talk to your vet about what tests are necessary. Proper testing will give the veterinarian more information to base a diagnosis on. The vet draws up a mental problem list of the conditions that are most likely to present with the dog's history and physical signs. The vet will then target tests for this. A routine starting point is screening blood tests to look at organ function plus red and white cells. This tells the vet if there are problems with the organs and also if the dog is dehydrated or anemic and if this is have a deleterious effect on the organs. X Research source
children:
A routine starting point is screening blood tests to look at organ function plus red and white cells. This tells the vet if there are problems with the organs and also if the dog is dehydrated or anemic and if this is have a deleterious effect on the organs.[6]
	X
		Research source

step_items.content: Discuss the need for a specific diagnosis with you veterinarian. It's not always necessary to make a specific diagnosis because, with supportive care, the dog will fight the condition and get better on its own. Testing may just increase your veterinary bill and not help with finding the right treatment.

Approve additional blood testing if your veterinarian thinks it is necessary. The vet may analyze the results of initial blood tests and then decide on additional tests to do. This might be additional blood tests to back up suspicions. For example, if the vet suspects pancreatitis, they might order a specific blood test, a spec CPL, to confirm the suspicion. Changes in electrolyte levels may point in another direction, such as a suspicion of Addison's disease. Then an ACTH stimulation test is necessary to follow up and make a definite diagnosis.
children: For example, if the vet suspects pancreatitis, they might order a specific blood test, a spec CPL, to confirm the suspicion.
Changes in electrolyte levels may point in another direction, such as a suspicion of Addison's disease. Then an ACTH stimulation test is necessary to follow up and make a definite diagnosis.

step_items.content: Discuss the need for other types of testing. Blood tests may not tell the veterinarian everything he or she needs to know to give a definitive diagnosis. For instance, it might be necessary to image the abdomen to look at the size and shape of organs, and to check the gas patterns in the bowel, since this can give useful information. There are different ways to image the abdomen. Radiography is a common diagnostic tool and gives and black and white image. Alternatively, an ultrasound scan may be appropriate. This has the advantage of giving a gray-scale image of the internal structures and can also look inside the organs. If no obvious answer turns up on blood tests and imaging, then it may be necessary to biopsy the area of interest. If a bowel problem is suspected, then open laparotomy to remove a sample of gut to send to a pathologist may be necessary. Bowel biopsies in particular are associated with a high complication rate so your vet will discuss this option with your carefully prior to proceeding.
children: There are different ways to image the abdomen. Radiography is a common diagnostic tool and gives and black and white image. Alternatively, an ultrasound scan may be appropriate. This has the advantage of giving a gray-scale image of the internal structures and can also look inside the organs.

If no obvious answer turns up on blood tests and imaging, then it may be necessary to biopsy the area of interest. If a bowel problem is suspected, then open laparotomy to remove a sample of gut to send to a pathologist may be necessary. Bowel biopsies in particular are associated with a high complication rate so your vet will discuss this option with  your carefully prior to proceeding.

step_items.content: Follow your veterinarian's suggestions for treatment. This will vary dramatically depending on the cause of the sickness. It may consist of letting the dog rest and introducing a bland diet, to surgery for an internal problem. A bland diet for a dog usually consists of a lean protein mixed with rice. It is easy to digest and allows the dog's digestive system to recover more easily.
children: A bland diet for a dog usually consists of a lean protein mixed with rice. It is easy to digest and allows the dog's digestive system to recover more easily.
